questions.text: A child rescued from a trafficking ring is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the above X-ray image of the wrist and hand, all the carpal bones are seen. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft. This suggests that the age of the child is 12 to 15 years.

The age of ossification of the carpal bones:

Carpal bone Age of ossification
Capitate 1-3 months
Hamate

2-4 months
Triquetrum

2-3 years
Lunate 2-4 years
Scaphoid 4-6 years
Trapezium 4-6 years
Trapezoid 4-6 years  
Pisiform 8-12 years  

The age of fusion of joints:

Bone/ joint Maximum age at fusion

Elbow joint centers

Metacarpals

 16 years
Wrist joint centers 19 years
Hip bone centers 22 years

questions.text: An ICU patient dies due to cardiac failure. After some time, you notice that the deceased body has become cold. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of cooling of the body following a death is called algor mortis/ postmortem cooling.

After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. It is one of the early changes occurring after death. Temperature is usually measured in the rectum or abdominal cavity (subhepatic region).

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B IPC. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C)/ Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options - 

Option A - Death by rash or negligent act is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C - Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.  Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS.

Option D -  Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC (Sec.116 BNS). Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a patient who died of suspected poisoning, it was noted that he had pink-coloured skin and mucosa. Prior to death, he had a bitter almond smell from his breath and frothy discharge.  What is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards cyanide poisoning.

Poisoning by cyanide:

  • Cyanides are protoplasmic cytotoxic poisons.
  • They act by inhibiting cytochrome oxidases for utilising O2 in a cell, leading to internal asphyxia (cellular asphyxia), leading to death.
  • It can also act on other enzymes mildly.
  • It also acts as a corrosive on mucosa.
  • Inhalation brings about death instantaneously by respiratory arrest.

Clinical Features in small doses

  • Saltish taste in mouth
  • Smell of bitter almonds to the breath
  • Salivation, nausea, vomiting
  • Cyanosis

Clinical Features in large doses

  • Rapid loss of consciousness, convuslions, coma, death
  • Very often found deadat the scene 

Treatment of cyanide poisoning:

  • Nitrites (Amyl nitrite,Sodium nitrite) are given to convert haemoglobin to methaemoglobin.
  • Cyanides combine with methaemoglobin to form cyanmethaemoglobin , which in the presence of rhodonase & sodium thiosulphate converts cyanide to thiocyanate which is excreted in urine.

Other antidotes:

  • Hydroxycobalamin (vitamin B12)
  • Dicobalt EDTA
  • PAPP(Para amino propio phenol)
 

Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate are the preferred antidotes in cyanide toxicity.

  • If hydroxocobalamin is available,  give hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate. 
  • If hydroxocobalamin is not available, give amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. Avoid nitrites if the patient has contraindications to nitrites.

Hydroxocobalamin is preferred over sodium nitrite as it does not interfere with the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. Also, sodium nitrite can induce fatal methemoglobinemia in patients who are critically ill from another cause.

Mechanism of action of antidotes:

Mechanism of antidote   Example
Binding of cyanide Direct binding of cyanide, followed by clearance Hydroxocobalamin
Induction of methemoglobinemia When cyanide binds methemoglobin, a relatively less toxic cyanomethemoglobin is formed

Sodium nitrite

Amyl nitrite
Use of sulfur donors This involves maximizing the availability of sulfur donors for rhodanese, a ubiquitous enzyme that detoxifies cyanide by transforming it to thiocyanate Sodium thiosulfate

Colour of post mortem lividity (hypostasis) in various conditions.

Condition Colour of hypostasis
Normal Bluish pink which later turns into bluish purple
Carbon monoxide poisoning Bright cherry red
Cyanide poisoning Pink
Phosphorus poisoning Dark brown
Nitrate poisoning Reddish brown
Chlorate poisoning Chocolate brown
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning Bluish Green
Aniline poisoning Deep blue
Opiate poisoning Black

Other options:

Option A: Carbon monoxide poisoning shows the characteristic postmortem staining with bright cherry red discoloration.

Option C: Hydrogen sulphide poisoning shows characteristic blue-green staining.

Option D: Datura poisoning predominantly presents with peripheral anticholinergic effects like flushed face, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils, delirium, urinary retention, etc. with central effects like psychosis and delirium.

Related Pearl: Characteristic odour of toxins

Toxins Odour emitted
Arsenic, Phosphorous Malathion, Thallium, aluminium phosphide Garlic odour
Cannabis Odour of burnt rope
Carbolic acid Phenolic odour
Cyanide Smell of bitter almonds
Ethyl alcohol Fruity odour
Hydrogen sulphide Rotten egg
Zinc phosphide  Fishy / Garlicky odour
Kerosene, Organophosphorous-insecticides Smell of kerosene

questions.text: Olive Green colored urine is seen in poisoning with:
questions.solution:
Olive green urine is seen in carbolic acid poisoning.

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Post mortem, the viscera should be preserved in a saturated salt solution. The skin has a reddish appearance with necrosis or ulceration. The body has a characteristic phenolic odor. The esophagus may look reddish and like parchment. The internal surface of the stomach may show prominent rugae with a leathery appearance, due to the opaque, coagulated, grey, or brown mucosa.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Such questions are permitted during which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.

As per section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act, a leading question is one which is suggestive of the answer that is desired or one which includes a fact and leads to the admitting of a conclusive answer, such as yes or no.

Cross-examination is one wherein the witness is questioned by the opposite party's lawyer, i.e the lawyer for the accused or the defense lawyer. It is undertaken with the objective to demonstrate favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and to discredit the witness.

The sequence of examination while recording evidence is as follows:

  1. Examination-in-Chief/direct examination by the party that summoned the witness to elicit all the facts from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed (option C). The only exception is if the judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile. 
  2. Cross-examination is done by the defence lawyer.
  3. Re-examination is done by the party that summoned the witness to correct or clarify or detail the statements made by the witness during cross-examination. Leading questions are not allowed (option A).

Other options:

Option D: A dying declaration is an oral or written statement made by a person who is dying. The doctor should certify that the person is conscious and with normal mental faculties before the declaration is recorded. It is recorded by the executive magistrate, or a doctor in the presence of two witnesses, if there is no time for the magistrate to come. Leading questions should not be asked.

questions.text: For a man to be found guilty of statutory rape, he must have had sexual intercourse with?

choices.text: A woman who is in intoxicated state
His wife living under decree of separation
Any person other than his wife
A girl below 18 years of age with her consent

questions.solution:
Statutory rape is having a sexual relationship with a girl who is below 18 years of age even with her consent.

Sexual intercourse with a woman who is under the influence of sedative drugs like GHB, rohypnol (flunitrazepam) is called date rape. 

Sexual intercourse with wife living separately, against her consent is marital rape. 

Voluntary sexual intercourse between a married person and a person who is not their spouse is adultery.

Note: Adultery used to be a punishable offence under Section 497 IPC. It was scapped down by the Supreme Court on 6th September 2018, and is no longer punishable.

questions.text: In organophosphorus poisoning, clinical manifestations occur when pseudocholinesterase levels fall below:
questions.solution:
In organophosphorus poisoning, clinical signs and symptoms are observed when pseudocholinesterase level falls below 50% of normal. 

  • Mild poisoning: 40-50% of normal
  • Moderate poisoning: 10-40% of normal
  • Severe poisoning: <10% of normal

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom?
questions.solution:
Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom. 

The venom is a clear, colorless, proteinous toxalbumen, having a hemolytic and neurotoxic effect. Its toxicity is more than that of snakes, but only a small quantity is injected. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local and simulates the viper snake bite. The scorpion sting will have only one hole in the center of the reddened area. The extremity will have edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours.

The symptoms produced by a neurotoxic venom are similar to a cobra bite. There is usually no marked reaction in the local area. Nausea, vomiting, extreme restlessness, fever, various types of paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, convulsions, coma, respiratory depression, and death may occur within hours from pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.

Prazosin can counteract the alpha-adrenergic effects of autonomic stimulation, such as hypertension.

questions.text: Human skeletal remains were found in an abandoned basement in Wuhan. Which of the following would indicate that the victim was a Caucasian?

choices.text: Lack of the third upper molar

questions.solution:
Carabelli’s cusps are most commonly seen only in Caucasian races and rare in the other major racial groups. These are small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars.

The image below shows Carabelli’s cusps seen in Caucasian races.

Features of mongoloid dentition include:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a central depression
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Taurodontism (bull-tooth) - Pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar

The image below shows shovel-shaped upper central incisors seen in mongoloid races compared to non-shovel shaped incisors:

questions.text:
Which of the following are constituents of smokeless gunpowder?
  1. Nitrocellulose
  2. Potassium nitrate
  3. Nitroglycerine
  4. Nitroguanidine
  5. Sulphur
questions.solution:
Smokeless gunpowder contains nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose and nitroguanidine.

Related Pearl: Various types of gunpowder

  • Smokeless powder:
    • Nitrocellulose (single base)
    • Nitrocellulose & Nitroglycerine (double base)
    • Nitrocellulose, Nitroglycerine, and Nitroguanidine (triple base)
  • Smoke producing powders contain Black Powder:
    • Potassium nitrate
    • Charcoal
    • Sulphur
  • Semi-smokeless powder:
    • Mixture of 80% black and 20% of the smokeless powder

questions.text: A woman was drugged with a substance, which was slipped into her coffee without her knowledge by a man at her workplace. The man confessed that he tried to make her notice him by adding a love philter to her coffee. Which of the following would he have used?
questions.solution:
A love philter is a magical potion that is supposed to make the person who receives the potion love the one who gave it. These are usually aphrodisiacs.

Some aphrodisiacs that are used as love philter are:

  • Cantharides
  • Arsenic
  • Alcohol
  • Opium
  • Cocaine
  • Cannabis

The use of a love philter might lead to accidental poisoning.

questions.text: The least common fingerprint pattern is _____________.
questions.solution:
Composite type (1-2%) is the least common fingerprint pattern.

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops - Most common type (60-70%)
  • Whorl - (25-30%)
  • Arch - (6-7%) They may be plain, tented, or exceptional. 
  • Composite forms (1 – 2%) - least common

The study of ridge patterns in the skin is Dactylography/ Galton-Henry system/ Dermatoglyphics. Fingerprints are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips.

Classification of fingerprints into different patterns is based on delta and core formation. Delta is a triangular arrangement formed where three separate ridge line flows come together. The core is the centermost portion of a ridge flow pattern. 

The number of delta and core for each pattern is given below.

Pattern  Delta  Core
Loop 1 1
Plain arch 0 0
Tented arch 1 delta at the base of the upthrust 0
Whorl 2 1

The image given below shows the delta and core in the different fingerprint patterns. For each type, the position of the core is marked with a green circle, and the delta is marked with a blue triangle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female was admitted for a strangulated femoral hernia. She came with complaints of abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and recession of intestines with an end to end anastomosis. The next day she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate as it is the disease/condition directly leading to death.

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Peritonitis
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: Perforation of small intestine
  • I(c) - Condition which gave rise to the antecedent cause: Strangulated femoral hernia

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs of death and provide no useful information as to the underlying disease process.

Refer the last line in the death certificate with an asterisk (*).

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: First-hand knowledge rule is applicable to:
questions.solution:
The first-hand knowledge rule is applicable to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him.

An expert witness is someone who has been trained or is skilled or has knowledge and experience and is able to draw conclusions from the facts observed by him. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract, and are passed entirely in the faeces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.

Patients typically present with symptoms similar to tetanus such as

  • Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic. The anti-gravity muscles experience the most severe convulsions, causing the body to typically arch in hyperextension—a position called opisthotonus.
  • Risus sardonicus which results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back.
  • If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonus).
  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates and the patients should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

  • Mnemonic to remember signs and symptoms.
  • We know that CRAMPing of muscles leads to the exhaustive death of the person in strychnine poisoning. Therefore:
    • Convulsions
    • Reflex increased
    • Awful taste
    • Mind is conscious
    • Pupils dilated
  • Clonic-tonic convulsions
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus: fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Medico-legal implications:.

  • Although a poison, in relatively low doses can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: A deceased male was posted for a ​post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes should be examined in this case.

Some amount of material or dye used for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Hence in cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined before making any conclusions.

questions.text: Among the following criteria, which is the most reliable criterion for age determination from Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
According to Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion.

Gustafson's method of estimating the age of an individual is based on physiological changes in dental tissues. It is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age (option B).

Gustafson’s criteria:

  • Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication
  • Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity
  • Cementum apposition - Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root due to changes in the tooth position. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves 
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Other options:

Option C - Weight and height of the erupting teeth of a child are used to estimate the age of infants by Stack's method, not Gustafson's method.

Option D -  Chemical methods for estimation of the nitrogen content of enamel, which increases with age, are used for estimating the age beyond 25 years. It is not a part of Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: All of the following confirm a live birth except:

choices.text: Presence of milk in the stomach
Presence of meconium in the large bowel

questions.solution:
Absence (and not presence) of meconium in the large bowel is a confirmatory sign of live birth.

Confirmatory signs of live birth are :

  • Presence of milk in the stomach
  • Absence of meconium in the large bowel, exception being breech delivery.
  • Exfoliation of skin
  • Closure of foetal channels
  • Changes in the umbilical cord

Live birth can be excluded if :

  • Signs of maceration are present
  • Signs of immaturity are present. If the child has not attained the viable age (7 months), it could not have been born alive.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable indicator that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress?

choices.text: Vital reaction in the burned area
Redness of the exposed skin surface

questions.solution:
Elevated levels of carbon monoxide in the circulating blood and carbon particles in the air passages and lungs are reliable indicators suggesting that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress.

They do not prove that any burns were ante-mortem, but that the victim was still alive when the fire was in progress, which is not the same conclusion.

Trait

Ante-mortem burns

Post-mortem burns

Line of redness

Present

Absent

Blister

Contains serous fluid with proteins and chlorides

Base is inflamed

Contains air only

Base is dry, hard and yellow.

Vital-reaction

Present

Absent

Enzymes

Peripheral zone of burn shows increase in enzyme reaction

Peripheral zone of burn does not show increase in enzyme reaction

 

Related Pearl: Differences between antemortem and postmortem burns

 

Characteristics Antemortem burns Postmortem burns
Line of redness+vital sign Present Absent
Vesication Present and true, contains serous fluid

Present but are false, contains PM gases
Reparative process Present Absent
Internal organs Congested

Usually roasted+emits peculiar odour
Blood Cherry red due to CO Not so
Curling’s ulcer Present Absent
Inflamed Payer’s patches Present Absent

Carbon/ soot particles in trachea, bronchus

 Present  Absent

questions.text: The preauricular sulcus is an indicator of:
questions.solution:
The preauricular sulcus is a groove on the iliac bone found in a female pelvis. It is absent in a male pelvis and hence can be used for sex determination.

Important differentiating features between male and female pelvis are:

Characteristic Male pelvis Female pelvis
General Morphology Rugged with marked muscle attachments Gracile and smooth
Overall shape Pelvis is high and narrow Pelvis is wide and shallow
Pubic bone Narrow and triangular Wide and rectangular
Subpubic angle Narrow (70 degrees) Wide (90 degrees)
Greater sciatic notch J-shape L-shape
Preauricular sulcus Absent Present

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

choices.text: Police not under rank of  sub inspector

questions.solution:
In the case of civil negligence, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence.

questions.text: What type of skull fracture is shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a gutter fracture of the skull.

It is a furrow in the outer table of the skull, ordinarily the result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These are frequently accompanied with comminuted depressed fractures of inner table of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning?

1. Raindrop pigmentation
2. Peripheral neuritis
3. Mees line
4. Luminous vomit
questions.solution:
Among the given options, raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and mees line are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning. Luminous vomit is a feature of yellow phosphorous poisoning. 

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

In chronic arsenic poisoning, skin symptoms include erythematous lesions, flushing, and can also lead to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Pigmentation is patchy and resembles raindrops on a dusty road. In the distal parts of the body, hyperkeratosis is present.  Mees lines are transverse white striae of the fingernails, called striate leukonychia. Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera-like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • Prolonged QT interval
  • Ventricular fibrillation
  • Atypical ventricular tachycardia

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to Blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: The wound in the given image is most likely to have been produced by?
questions.solution:
The image shows 'tram-line' bruising, most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle. 

Tram-line bruising:

  • When the skin surface is struck by a rod or rectangular sectioned object such as a cane or lath, the consequent bruising may be of the ‘tram-line’ or ‘railway line’ type.
  • The mechanism of this double line is that the weapon sinks into the skin on impact so that the edges drag the skin downwards and the traction tears the marginal blood vessels. The centre compresses the skin, which, in the absence of underlying bone, causes little or no damage to the vessels.

questions.text: As per The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, Induction of MTP in a  mentally ill, rape victim is allowed until what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill 2020, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill or rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks. 

 

Salient features of amendments:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors) etc.
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit not to apply in cases of substantial foetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorised in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptive has been extended to women and her partner.

 

Note: The bill has been passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act 1971

Indications :

  • Therapeutic : When continuation of pregnancy endangers the life of the woman, or may injure her physical or mental health. 
  • Eugenic : The risk of child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality. This includes first trimester viral infections, maternal drug intake (thalidomide, cortisone, antimitotics), xray or radioisotope treatment of the mother, insanity of parents and viral hepatitis.
  • Humanitarian : Pregnancy resulted from rape.
  • Social : Pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives. 

Rules :

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government recognised hospital.
  • Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is a minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband is not necessary.
  • If the woman is not willing, abortion can not be performed on the request of the husband alone.
  • The woman need not produce proof of her age. The statement of the woman that she is over 18 years of age is accepted.
  • It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.
  • Professional secrecy has to be maintained.
  • If the period of pregnancy is below 20 weeks, it can be terminated on the opinion of a single doctor.
  • If the period of pregnancy is between 20-24 weeks, two doctors must opine that there is an indication. Once there is an indication, the termination can be done by any one doctor.
  • In an emergency, the termination can be done by a single doctor, even without the required training, even after 20 weeks, without consulting a second doctor, in a private hospital which is not recognised. 
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years.

Confidentiality :

The head of the hospital must maintain a register for recording the details of MTP. This register is a secret document which should be kept under safe custody for five years, and each patient is given a reference number. The name of the patient should not be entered anywhere, any case sheet or operation theatre register or any other record.

questions.text: In Breslau’s second life test, the organ tested is _______
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test the organ tested is Stomach and intestine.

BRESLAU’S SECOND LIFE TEST:

  • It is based on air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live born foetus.
  • Stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.
  • Inference:
  • A floating viscera giving out air-bubbles when opened under water is positive test and suggestive of live birth.
  • False positive – in case of stillbirth, air might enter the stomach when child tries to free obstruction of air passages.
  • Mucus, saliva and air bubbles in stomach – breathing has occurred.
  • Only mucus – breathing has not occurred.
  • Blood, meconium, liquor amnii in stomach – child alive at or shortly before birth.
  • Milk in stomach – child was alive for sometime after birth.
  • Test is invalid in case of putrefaction.

questions.text: A man regularly derives sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon his partner. He would often produce cuts and cigarette burns on his partner's arms. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism - It is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetishism - It is a form of sexual behaviour in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism - This is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. What is the maximum time by which the practitioner can take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
A vaginal swab of a rape victim demonstrates spermatozoa if the vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours after an assault.

However vaginal swab can be taken within 96 hours to demonstrate semen.

Evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing can be collected even after 96 hours.
